comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: A Streetview of those buildings from a point at the right middle of shot, behind the seawall, at the top of those steps. The OS 25" names this as St. Patrick's Sawmill. Not sure how St. Patrick feels about that!

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: NIAH says the sawmill is from 1863.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: As you can see from Niall's comments above, this one had been in our Munsterset for quite some time (neglected by everyone but him). It just happens to be the Then of the Lawrence Photographic Project Now photograph - Now being 1990, but we won't fall out over 23 years... :)
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: Well it's after 1844 anyway. That's the date on the 6" and it's not on that.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: In fact, after 1858 - the railway's there already.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: I've added a note above the cliff face - I see a railing up there. Comparing the 1844 6" and the 1898 25", that path goes up the hill to a Spring Rice memorial. The NIAH dates that memorial as 1890-1910, not much help.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] While I think, from the line of the hill, that you're correct that there's a path there, I think your railling is a fallen tree. (Not particularly helpful criticism, I know, but we get the real gen on these pictures because we're pedants).

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: I was curious about the Spring-Rice memorial as the one I am more familiar with is in the Peoples Park in the city centre close to the Railway Station. It seems that it is a cross erected by the tenants of the Mount Trenchard and Ballycormick estates. This was erected some time after 1865 so that will not help here. see www.limerickcity.ie/media/letter%20to%20lord%20monteagle.pdf It seems that Spring-Rice was a decent auld sod and treated his tenants well.

comment.author: 38401430@N06
comment._content:
The chaps are actually debating inventing seaplanes and then flying people to the USA from Foynes so that they could invent "Irish Coffee" to quell seasickness at Foynes!

It's true Foynes was the birthplace of Irish Coffee. (And it was actually invented by Pan Am!)

comment.author: 78819959@N00
comment._content: It is told in my family that the bearded man with hat is Jeremiah O'Connor manager of the sawmill and resident in the large house shown. He died 1922. I am his great grandson

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/92onthehills] Hello Gerard, and apologies for slow reply! Thank you very much for your information. I've added a note on Jeremiah in the photo and in the description above.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons
